title: What are the consequences of illegal and unethical uses of information technologies? - Quora

response.answer_text: If YOU make unethical or illegal use of information technology you could go to jail, or lose your job, or friends and I will likely think you are a jerk (but see Aaron Swartz as a counter example). Or you could make a lot of money (See Ashley Madison). The consequences for others though, is more complicated. While unethical or illegal conduct in any area is harmful to individuals and society, such uses of information technology are particularly odious. The consequences are vast and imperative to address. Outlined below: Break down in trust Trust in expertsWhen experts fail to protect, or worse are complicit, it teaches people to be suspicious of expert opinion. Most harmful in technical areas where solutions are often counter intuitive.Trust in governmentEspecially when government is the bad actor.Trust in other people, organizations, companiesTrust in things you don’t understand, or have limited experience or information in.See: climate change, space programs, the justice system, medical treatments, etc. Flat earth and moon landing conspiracies are examples of both the causes and effects of this.Loss of privacy Also adding to the complexity of privacy – forcing us to consider the nature of privacyHow can we both protect political dissidents and expose corrupt interference with electionsEmbarrassmentLoss of AnonymityLoss of control over what is disclosed and to whomMacroeconomic and micro-economic harm Increased spending on risk management in generalIncreased spending on security and protection of information, translating to increased costs to consumers.Loss of opportunities (to share information, extract meaning, research)Wasting resourcesLoss of salesLoss of job opportunitiesSetting a bad example for future generations Creating a new normal that harms the social fabric and self-perpetuatesHelping other criminality Organized crime benefits through exploiting new attack vectorsHelps criminals avoid enforcementHelps criminals launder and monetize illicit gainsHelping authoritarian states Manipulating information is one of the most common and effective tactics of such regimesSee China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, etc.Maintaining and amplifying (unreasonably or unfairly) power imbalance based on economic power Those with money and power are more likely to benefit from the ability to discover information and exploit it unfairly.Gatekeepers of information like Facebook, google can unfairly maintain effective monopolies or exert undue influenceBenefits of these institutions are also harmed when they are the victimHindering progress If the small group of physicists working on the early internet were hacking and DDOS’ing each other, how would that have affected the world?footnotes: Aaron Swartz - Wikipedia

The systematic and totalitarian tracking of everything someone does and using it to oppress those who don’t fit an ideal mold. The subtle mix of incentives and disincentives to gain compliance in every area. And China’s Sesame Credit score is the perfect example of this. China’s social credit score and Big Brother 2.0: the trustworthy get perks, the discredited get punished - Richard van Hooijdonk Big data meets Big Brother as China moves to rate its citizens All Chinese citizens now have a score based on how well we live, and mine sucks Criticize the government too much, and you can’t hold certain jobs, travel abroad or within the country, pay more for services and get downranked in the top dating apps.
